newsitem.title: UK: World metal prices take another hit.
newsitem.headline: World metal prices take another hit.

text.p: World industrial metal prices took another turn for the worse on Monday, extending recent declines as bearish sentiment swamped the market.
Traders said consumer interest for all metals remained soft despite low prices, scotching hopes of a pick-up in demand during the traditionally busy September buying period.
Aluminium, used mainly in transport and packaging, slumped to a 2-1/2 year low of $1,414 a tonne on the London Metal Exchange (LME), down $22 from Friday's closing levels.
Rising stocks and only sporadic buying interest left the market vulnerable to further losses, traders said.
Recent stock increases also weighed on the lead market, which slumped three percent, or $24 to $785.
Nickel fell to a 2-1/2 week low of $7,350 despite weekend production cutbacks at Inco's plant in Manitoba, Canada, while tin matched Friday's six-week nadir of $6,110.
Copper and zinc were less volatile, finishing the day with limited losses.
In other commodity markets there was good news for those concerned about the risk of high food and oil prices fuelling inflation.
Chicago soybeans broke below the key $8.00-a-bushel barrier, with November slipping 13 cents to $7.89. Wheat futures were seven cents lower at $4.22.
Oil was also weaker as tensions in the Middle East appeared to be easing.

The nearby futures contract for the benchmark North Sea Brent Blend on the International Petroleum Exchange in London was trading below $22.40 per barrel compared with a post-Gulf War high at $24.39 on September 12.
In the tropical commodity markets, sugar values slumped in relatively thin trade, cocoa edged higher and coffee was mixed.
The London Commodity Exchange (LCE) is now trading under the London International Financial Futures (LIFFE) banner after a merger of these two markets that took effect on Monday.
The goal of the merger was to rescue the smaller LCE from a likely U.S. takeover and promote trading in grains in Europe.
In precious metals palladium was trading alost at the lowest in three years at 120.50/121.50 an ounce. Dealers cited slack demand and plentiful supply.
Some key commodity prices as at 1600 GMT on Monday -
Monday Friday
IPE Brent ($/barrel) (Oct) 22.39 24.22
(Ldn Metal Exchange)
COPPER (three months/tonne) 1,862.00 1,870.00
(Ldn futures)
COCOA (sterling/tonne) (Dec) 994.00 989.00
WHITE SUGAR ($/tonne) (Oct) 333.00 338.00
